content.description:
Starting at the seam for

Hungry Wolf

, make your way up some cool sidepulls and jams until you exit the seam to the right, pulling the shouldery crux.

Hungry

then splits right here to join

Stuffed Wolf

, but you stay left and rejoin the seam for some easier (but not easy) moves and a solid hand jam rest to the top. It seems to have clean up well and climbs very well. It can be used as a warm-up for the harder routes. The cruxy nature might give some the impression of 12a or 12b depending.
content.protection: Bolts to chains. On 11/15, there were fixed draws.
content.location:
Use the same start as

Hungry...

, downhill from

Stuffed...

.

content.description: This is the right route on the wall. It joins the left route near the top. Powerful moves right off the deck deposit you to the right a bit. A brilliant, pinchy crux leads you right into the crux of Hungry Wolf (the left route 12d/13a). Keep it together to the anchors. It's pumpy all the way.

content.protection:
10 bolts and two bolt lower-off with fixed biners. Use caution lowering back to the ledge.

Belayer should either wear a helmet, or get the hell out of the way of any droppings. This is another reason I put the belay slightly right of the climbing line.
content.location:
Start from a two bolt belay about 20 feet left and down the ramp from

Stuffed Wolf

. USE EXTRA CAUTION TO NOT SLIP OFF THIS RAMP LEDGE. It is possible to rap from this anchor about 60 feet to ground.

content.description:
(This appears on page 146 of the Mabe guidebook.)

"Until the mid '90s, this was the only route at High Profile. Start with the angling crack and continue up the past-vertical wall. Stout."

Start left of the direct variation,

Stuffed Wolf

and climb moderate ledges. Make either a slow, deliberate transfer or a wild huck out to the positive rail out right, and continue up the feature until you once again need to transfer right into the crux of the route. Do a series of finger locks and then a mixed, burl/core move using an undercling, then all that is left is holding on until the top.
content.protection: 6 bolts and fixed chains with steel carabiners at the top.
content.location:
Park 8.8 miles up the canyon in a pull-out on the south side (marker 263). Cross the river and head up and left to the obvious crag.

Easy 5th class climbing will get you to the ledge with belay anchors and enough room to sit down comfortably.

content.description:
This is the left-facing dihedral with a crack to the right of “

Crack

”. This crack is smaller than the obvious one to the left. It is pretty easy until about two thirds of the way up near the top. There was an old piton just below the crux area, but I pulled it out by hand. It would not have been trustworthy anyway and small cams work here. The crux is short and is just before you top out. It has poor feet, but the crack is good for the hands.
content.protection:
A standard rack up to a #2 Camalot. At the top, you can anchor to the rappel tree or at the same place as “

Crack

” with gear. There are two ancient quarter inch bolts in line with the climb.
content.location:
Start at the same place as “

Crack

,” but move to the right towards the dihedral as you ascend. There are some small bushes to move through just before you get to the actual crack.

content.description: This is the crack which faces west and is easily seen from the road when driving east. It looks like a offwidth crack from the road but is actually a nice hand crack. It has a thin section near its bottom, and the crux is near the upper part of the crack. There are several nice ledges to stand on which make it fairly easy to climb.
content.protection: A standard rack, but extra #1-3 Camalots are nice to sew it up. Build a gear anchor at the top. You can walk off to the northwest or there is webbing on the big tree at the top for a rappel.
content.location: This is on the west face of the rock to the right of the approach scramble to the crag's other climbs. There may be a fixed rope on the approach climb. This climb starts to the right of this approach on a higher ledge.
